repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Power Sector Restructuring and
            Transmission Expansion Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability highly unlikely, and
            institutional development impacts are negligible.
            Consequently, the performance of the borrower is rated
            highly unsatisfactory, primarily due to the inability to
            meet its commitments to initiate improvements in Electricite
            du Liban (EdL) operations, and financial management, and, to
            introduce legislation restructuring, and privatizing the
            sector, as agreed under the Action Plan. Similarly, the Bank
            performance is rated unsatisfactory, due to serious flaws in
            project design, inadequate back-up plans to improve
            EdL's financial viability, and management, and lack of
            integrated investment programs for the medium, and high
            voltage transmission lines, among others. Lessons of general
            experience suggest that legal, and institutional reforms be
            implemented prior to Bank commitments; consideration be
            given to the inclusion of cross effectiveness conditions
            with major lending institutions, when integrated
            transmission systems require completion of all components to
            be fully effective - this could have greatly increased
            incentives for the Government to schedule a timely approval
            of the financial package; technology issues need to be
            reviewed, and resolved prior to Board presentation, which
            could have avoided the long, drawn-out procurement of the
            Baalbeck and Saida transformer substations. Lessons
            specifically for Bank lending in Lebanon, suggest particular
            consideration to the use of the Council for Development and
            Reconstruction, as the project procurement organization,
            whenever the procurement process of implementing agencies
            require several layers of internal, and external formal
            approval; and, monitorable institutional processes should be
            considered to ensure access to local financial resources,
            required for expropriations, and resettlement issues.

repnme.cdata!:
World Bank guarantee electrifies
            Lebanon's power sector

abstracts.cdata!:
The note expands on the partial credit
            guarantee for the US$100 million bond issue, which helped
            mobilize the necessary financing to fund the financing gap
            for the Lebanon Power Sector Restructuring project. The
            guarantee was successful in catalyzing private financing for
            the power sector from the capital markets. Electricite du
            Liban (EDL) is in the process of recovering from 17 years of
            damage caused by the civil war. It would have been difficult
            for EDL to access the commercial capital markets under its
            own name. Therefore, while EDL is undergoing restructuring,
            and sector reforms are in progress, the Government of
            Lebanon has borrowed on behalf of EDL in order to maximize
            the terms of the borrowing sought under the partial credit
            guarantee. The extended maturity, the diversified investor
            base, and the tightened spread, all achieved with the help
            of the World Bank guarantee, should help to act as a
            catalyst for future investments in Lebanon.

repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Power Sector Restructuring and
            Transmission Expansion Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of this Power Sector
            Restructuring and Transmission Expansion Project are to: a)
            expand the high voltage transmission system to meet an
            integrated system peak demand of approximately 1,500 MW at
            the N-1 level of reliability; and b) to assist the borrower
            in implementing the action program in the Letter of Sectoral
            Development Policy (LSDP) which provides for establishing an
            enabling environment for private sector involvement in the
            power section, including the institutional restructuring of
            the sector.  The project comprises two elements: a) an
            investment component which will include double and single
            circuit 220-kV transmission lines, underground 220-kV cables
            and new 220-kV substations; and b) an institutional
            development component consisting of technical assistance for
            project implementation, training, and assistance to
            implement the institutional reform action program defined in
            the Government's LSDP.
